Children's birthdays, they mostly involve cake, balloons and a huge pile of presents.
But for some those presents present a problem, they're just too much.
And some parents are putting a stop to it.
Earlier I spoke with one such parent.
She is Slate editor Emily Bazelon and she has a different approach that she took with her son Eli.
Emily, really no more presents?
Well, not quite.
The problem that we were dealing with was feeling sort of surrounded by plastic and by lots and lots of toys.
And Eli's birthday is in January so it comes right after the holiday season and that made it feel particularly unwelcome.

Anyway, when Eli turned three and he was having his first birthday party we decided that we would ask each family to bring a wrapped book and that we would exchange the books among the kids at the party.
So Eli would come away with a present and so would all the other kids.
And I guess at age three he really didn't know what he was missing.
No, he didn't mind at all.
In fact, he didn't mind until quite recently.
A couple of months before his sixth birthday party he made it clear that from his point of view the book swap had run its course.
Okay, so you're confronted with your six-year-old's rebellion.
What did you do?
What did you decide?
Did you cave-in?
We didn't cave-in completely.
We felt strongly enough about this that we decided to compromise.
So we made Eli an offer.
We suggested that we would invite all the kids in his kindergarten class, which was what he wanted to do and which is sort of the ethic at his school, but we would ask five kids to bring presents.
He would even be able to choose which kids.
And then we would still do our book swap.
So all the other kids would bring books.
We would supply books for the kids who are bringing presents and there would be a book swap, but Eli would also come away with a few gifts.
And that mollified everyone?
It worked.
He went for it.
He thought, actually, that the pile of presents at his party was really big.
In fact, he told me at one point that we must have canceled the book swap because there were so many boxes for him.
And then he had a good time opening them.
So in the sense of the parents feeling okay about what had happened and the child feeling pleased, it was a pretty good success.
So you posted your article on slate.com last week and I understand you've been getting lots of reader feedback on it.
What do other parents think of your idea?
Well, I would say that the mail has definitely been running against me.
A few parents said, Hey, that's a great idea, and they described their own sort of issues with birthday parties and different solutions they'd come to.
I think a lot of people put away many of the presents and then sort of take them out gradually throughout the year, which seemed like a good solution to me.

And then there were a lot of people who were just horrified and thought that what my husband and I were doing was moralistic and really out of sync with the whole notion of a birthday, which is that a birthday is all about the child and shouldn't have any constraints.
So did that surprise you?
I was not particularly surprised because I think that whenever you decide to make a different choice for your kids that is sort of out of line with mainstream values, you have some explaining to do.
And it's amazing to me what a strong reaction it elicits.
You know, I didn't really think that what we were doing was particularly noteworthy or such a big deal, but there was this very intense sense that we were deviating.

And I think that whether, you know, you're deciding that your kid has to go to church rather than soccer practice or whatever choice you're imposing, if it's not the same choice that most other people are making, they are likely to take issue with it.
Opinion and analysis from Emily Bazelon.

You spent several years reporting on Somali-Americans in Minnesota who were being recruited by terrorist groups.

- Abdullahi Yusuf.
But what did you actually learn from sitting down with him face-to-face?
Well, he was part of the biggest ISIS recruitment and conspiracy trial we've ever had in the U.S.
Eleven young men in the Twin Cities were involved.
So I wanted to understand why these young men were attracted to the group.
For example, we keep hearing about ISIS videos radicalizing young people.
And Yusuf explains exactly how it affected him - how they seemed to tell him that he had the ability to change things in Syria if he just went there to fight.
I was mesmerized, you know, like - it was like, if you don't like it, go do something about it, and here's why you should go do something about it.
And it was just, check, check, check, check, that's me, that's me, that's me, that's me.
And, you know, sign me up.
Sign me up, Dina.
It sounds like he made this decision so quickly.
It was like a snap of the fingers.
It took weeks, not months.
He talks a lot about how he felt like he was the other in Minnesota, how he was living two lives.
You know, on one hand, he's on the high school football team, which suggests he's pretty assimilated.
But on the other, he was wondering about being a Somali in America - what his prospects were.
And what I found out, from talking to him, is what ISIS offers is simple answers for all that.
And you have to remember that he was 17 at the time.
And a lot of the Americans who are going to ISIS are really young.
They aren't thinking about attacking the U.S.
Instead, it's not so much about ideology.
It's about adolescent decision-making.

And I think there's a growing understanding about that in the court system, and that's why they're starting to look at alternatives to incarceration, like the program that Abdullahi Yusuf went through.
Yeah, I want to hear more about that program.
So you're saying the courts are beginning to think that in some cases, it is not a young person thinking, I'm going to become a terrorist and attack the United States.
They might be going to try and help people improve their lives in the Syrian civil war or something like that.
Exactly.
It - certainly less now than with what we know about ISIS, but at that time - and certainly for many young adolescent males - they think they're going to be heroes.
And the program that Yusuf went through to try and talk to him about this wasn't about religion or a reinterpretation of Islam, which is what most of the overseas jihadi rehab programs focus on.
Instead, partly because he was so young, his program really had to do a lot with critical thinking.
Research has shown that if you develop an adolescent's ability to question things critically, they tend to make better decisions.
And reading can be a very powerful way of doing that.
So what happened with Yusuf is that he worked with a nonprofit called Heartland Democracy, which works with at-risk kids and adults in the Twin Cities area.

And they gave him reading to do while he was in jail, while he was awaiting sentencing - things like ""Letters From Birmingham"" (ph), Malcolm X's biography, the Native American writer Sherman Alexie and even a little philosophy from the French philosopher Foucault.
